misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Program does not implement the requested problem at all
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a correct distance-between-points program instead of a grade calculator, so none of the required grade ranges or letter outputs are implemented.
misconceptions.student_belief: If I write any correct Java program that reads some numbers and computes a result, that is acceptable, even if it does not match the specific problem description.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must implement exactly what the problem statement asks for: read a single numeric grade (0–100), use conditional logic to determine which grade range it falls into (A–F), and print the corresponding letter grade.
symptoms: No variable representing a grade (0–100); instead uses x1, y1, x2, y2.
Input prompts ask for coordinates rather than a grade.
No if/else or conditional logic based on grade ranges.
Output describes the distance between points rather than a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between different assignment questions or copying a solution from another exercise without aligning it to this problem’s requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem description and list the exact inputs and outputs it requires. Start by reading a single numeric grade into a variable, then design an if/else-if/else chain that checks the grade ranges (90–100, 80–89, etc.) and prints the matching letter. Ignore unrelated problems like distance formulas when working on this question.
related_concepts: Mapping input/output requirements to code structure
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program consistently implements distance calculation and never references grades, ranges, or letter outputs, indicating a complete mismatch with the assignment.

evidence.note: The code reads four coordinates, computes a distance, and prints it; there is no grade input, no grade range logic, and no letter grade output as required.

misconceptions.name: Complete Misunderstanding of Problem Requirement
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to calculate the distance between two points instead of writing the requested Grade Calculator program. This indicates a complete failure to understand or attempt the assigned task.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have copied and pasted code from a completely different assignment (Distance Between Points) and submitted it for the Grade Calculator problem, believing this code satisfies the requirements, or perhaps not having read the prompt at all.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task required implementing a Grade Calculator using conditional logic (if-else) and reading a single numeric grade input. The provided code implements a distance calculation and should be replaced entirely.
symptoms: Program reads four inputs (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one (grade)
Program outputs a distance calculation result
No conditional logic (if/else statements) is present to determine a letter grade
Class name does not match the content (DistanceBetweenPoints vs GradeCalculator)
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely rushing, submitting the wrong file, or not reading the problem description, leading to a complete mismatch between the requirement and the implementation.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Read the problem description carefully and ensure the submitted code addresses the specific requirements of the 'Grade Calculator' problem, which requires reading a single numeric grade and outputting a letter grade based on ranges.
related_concepts: Reading Scanner Input for specific data types
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code snippet clearly calculates the distance between two points (using Math.sqrt and Math.pow) based on four inputs, which is entirely unrelated to calculating a letter grade from a single input.

evidence.note: The class name suggests a different problem entirely.
The code reads four coordinates instead of one numeric grade.

evidence.snippet: System.out.printf("The distance of the two points is %s%n", Math.sqrt(Math.pow(x2 - x1, 2) + Math.pow(y2 - y1, 2)));
evidence.note: The computation and output are for distance calculation, not grade determination.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Missing conditional logic for grade classification
misconceptions.description: The student has not implemented any conditional statements (if-else) to check grade ranges and classify numeric grades into letter categories.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student may believe that range checking and conditional logic is not required, or has not yet begun implementing the solution.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To map numeric grades to letter grades, the program must use if-else statements with Boolean conditions that check if the grade falls within each range (e.g., if (grade >= 90 && grade <= 100) for 'A').
symptoms: No if, else if, or else keywords in the code
No Boolean expressions checking grade values
Program cannot produce different letter grades for different numeric inputs
No logical structure to handle the five grade ranges
misconceptions.root_cause: Student either did not start implementing the problem or copied code from an unrelated assignment.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Add if-else if-else statements to check each grade range in order: (1) if grade >= 90, print 'A'; (2) else if grade >= 80, print 'B'; (3) continue for C, D, and F. Use && (AND) operator for conditions with both upper and lower bounds if needed.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code contains zero conditional logic. This is objectively missing, not a subtle misunderstanding.

evidence.note: No conditional statements (if/else) present. Program performs linear sequence of input and calculation without branching logic needed for grade classification.

misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Implemented distance calculator instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description:
The student wrote a complete and syntactically correct program, but it solves an entirely different problem: computing the distance between two points rather than mapping a numeric grade (0–100) to a letter grade.

Rubric scoring:
- Reading numeric grade input: 0/1 — The program reads four doubles (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single numeric grade.
- Correct Boolean ranges for A and B: 0/1 — There are no conditional checks for grade ranges; the program uses only arithmetic and Math.sqrt/Math.pow.
- Correct Boolean ranges for C and D: 0/1 — As above, no middle-range checks or conditionals appear.
- Correct handling of F (default/else): 0/1 — There is no default/else case or any conditional structure to catch grades below 60.
- Mapping each range to correct letter output: 0/1 — The output describes the distance between points, not a letter grade; no letter grades (A/B/C/D/F) are produced.
misconceptions.student_belief: I believe the task is to read two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) from the user and then compute and print the distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task is to read a single numeric grade between 0 and 100, then use conditional statements to determine which interval the grade falls into (A: 90–100, B: 80–89, C: 70–79, D: 60–69, F: below 60) and print the corresponding letter grade.
symptoms: Program prompts for coordinates ("Enter x1 and y1", "Enter x2 and y2") instead of a single grade.
Variables x1, y1, x2, y2 of type double are used, rather than a single numeric grade variable.
No if/else-if/else or switch statements are present to handle grade ranges.
The output message describes the distance between two points, not a letter grade.
Computation uses Math.sqrt and Math.pow instead of any range checks or letter mapping.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student likely reused code from a previous or different exercise (distance between points) or misread the assignment instructions, focusing on implementing a familiar example rather than the specified grade-to-letter mapping problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint:
Re-read the problem statement carefully and design the program specifically for the requested behavior.

1. Input: Use Scanner to read a single numeric grade (int or double) with a prompt like "Enter grade: ".
2. Logic: Use an if/else-if/else chain to check the grade ranges in order (>= 90 for A, >= 80 for B, >= 70 for C, >= 60 for D, else F). Make sure each range is inclusive and non-overlapping.
3. Output: Print the corresponding letter grade exactly as required, e.g., "Letter grade: B".
4. Compare your program’s behavior with the sample run to confirm that the prompts and output format match.

Overall feedback:
- Strengths: You demonstrate correct use of Scanner for numeric input and of the Math library (Math.sqrt, Math.pow). Your code is syntactically correct, well-structured, and closes the Scanner properly.
- Areas for improvement: Pay much closer attention to the problem specification and sample run. Before coding, restate the problem in your own words and outline the required input, processing (logic/conditions), and output. This will help ensure you implement the correct problem rather than a different example you remember.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the submitted program (input prompts, variable names, calculations, and output) corresponds to the classic 'distance between two points' exercise and does not reference grades or letter outputs at all, strongly indicating the student solved the wrong problem.

evidence.note: The code reads four doubles representing two points and computes the Euclidean distance, with no mention of grades, letter grades, or conditional checks required by the grade calculator problem.

evidence.note: The class name itself is highly indicative that the student is solving the wrong problem.

evidence.snippet: System.out.printf("The distance of the two points is %s%n", Math.sqrt(Math.pow(x2 - x1, 2) + Math.pow(y2 - y1, 2)));

misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment Q3 requires a grade calculator that reads one numeric grade (0-100) and outputs the corresponding letter grade (A-F). This is fundamentally different from computing distances between 2D points.

Program calculates and outputs distance using Math.sqrt() and Math.pow()
No conditional logic (if/else) for grade ranges
Output format is completely different from expected 'Letter grade: X'

misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the assignment requirements carefully. Implement a new solution that: (1) reads a single integer grade, (2) uses if-else conditionals to check grade ranges, and (3) outputs 'Letter grade: A/B/C/D/F'.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: 100% confidence - the submitted code is definitively for a different problem. The class name, input variables, computation method, and output format all correspond to a distance calculator, not a grade calculator.

evidence.note: This entire program solves a completely different problem (distance between 2D points using the Euclidean distance formula) rather than the assigned grade calculator. No grade ranges, no conditional logic, no letter grade output.
